currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Increased usage leads to a greater strain on our eye muscl


During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental 


During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. But we d


During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live i

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day.

This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit socie

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also bene

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choice

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by vb

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by vbe

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better und

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks.

Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with scr

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. In many ways, screens are such an impo

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. In many ways, screens are such an important part of life that they could never

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. In many ways, screens are such an important part of life that their use i

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. In many ways, screens are such an important part of life that their use is a nee

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. In many ways, screens are such an important part of life that their use should be i

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. In many ways, screens are such an important part of life that their use should be

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, screens are a clear and present danger in our lives. Despite this, screen use remains a necessary component of daily life. Because of this, we must remain more vigilant now than ever before about the potential negative impacts that it has on our daily lives. 

During the pandemic, the excessive screen use is resulting in lasting harm to health of our vision. This increase in usage often the result of sharp increases rather than a slow transition and is therefore more detrimental in the impact it has on our vision. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. Blue light has been linked to decreased retinal activity and has shown a statistically significant increase of early onset blindness in senior citizens who have reported more than 10 hours of screen time each day. 

Physical dangers aside, there is also a concern about the content that is behind the screen. We live in a time when truth and lies are blended together for our online consumption. This sharing of misinformation during a time when it is most important to have the best information possible has been extremely damaging to societys trust in our institutions. Any benefits gained are far outweighed by the risk to our relationships and to the stability of our society.

Despite all of this, screens use is not likely to change and we should therefore make sure to protect our eyesight as best we can. It would also benefit our choices by better understanding the dangers and risks attached with prolonged screen use. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
